dt: {bc}marked by or given to offhand and often disdainful {dx_def}see {dxt|disdain:1||}{/dx_def} dismissal of important matters

dt.t: has a {wi}cavalier{/wi} disregard for the rights of others

dt: {bc}of or relating to the party of Charles I of England in his struggles with the Puritans and Parliament

dt.t: portrayed the plantation owner as a {wi}cavalier{/wi} fop

dt: {bc}of or relating to the English Cavalier poets of the mid-17th century

shortdef: marked by or given to offhand and often disdainful dismissal of important matters
of or relating to the party of Charles I of England in his struggles with the Puritans and Parliament

dt: {bc}a gentleman trained in arms and horsemanship
{bc}an adherent of Charles I of England

et: borrowed from French, "horseback rider, member of the gentry bearing arms, gallant," going back to Middle French, borrowed from later medieval Italian {it}cavallere, cavaleru, cavalliere{/it} "horseback rider, mounted soldier, courtly gentleman accompanying a lady," borrowed from Old Occitan {it}cavalier{/it} "horseman, mounted soldier, knight," going back to Late Latin {it}caballārius{/it} "horseback rider, groom" (early Medieval Latin also "serf performing duties on horseback, mounted soldier"), from Latin {it}caballus{/it} "work horse, gelding" + {it}-ārius{/it} {et_link|-ary:1|-ary:1} {ma}{mat|cavalcade|}{/ma}
shortdef: a gentleman trained in arms and horsemanship
an adherent of Charles I of England

dt: {bc}any of a breed of toy spaniels developed in Great Britain from English toy spaniels and having a tapered muzzle and a long silky coat

et: {et_link|cavalier:2|cavalier:2} + {it}King Charles spaniel{/it}, a breed of toy spaniel, from {it}Charles{/it} II of England
shortdef: any of a breed of toy spaniels developed in Great Britain from English toy spaniels and having a tapered muzzle and a long silky coat
